qas.question: What law covers wrongs which humans can inflict upon each other?
Why can American tort law not be easily summarized?

answers.text: because of its immense size and diversity

qas.question: While attempting to standardize tort law, multiple versions of tort law have come about, what are there versions called?
What covers crimes of human against human?
What does tort law overlap with?

answers.text: wrongs also punishable by criminal law

qas.question: What is attempting to standardize the tort law system?
What is the Restatement of Torts not successfull as a whole yet?

answers.text: many states have chosen to adopt only certain sections

qas.question: Why is tort law hard to standardize?
What does tort not overlap with?
What tried to standardize criminal law?
What allows American tort law to be summarized easily?
The American Law Institute unstandardized what?
States have adopted all of what?

context: <a0_0><a3_0>Tort law<a3_0/><a0_0/> covers the entire imaginable spectrum of wrongs which humans can inflict upon each other, and of course, partially overlaps with <a4_0>wrongs also punishable by <b8_0>criminal law<b8_0/><a4_0/>. Although the <b9_0>American Law Institute<b9_0/> has attempted to standardize <b11_0>tort law<b11_0/> through the development of several versions of the <a2_0><a5_0><b10_0><b12_0>Restatement of Torts<b12_0/><b10_0/><a5_0/><a2_0/>, <a6_0>many states have chosen to adopt only certain sections<a6_0/> of the Restatements and to reject others. Thus, <a1_0>because of its <a7_0>immense size and diversity<a7_0/><a1_0/>, American tort law cannot be easily summarized.
